title: All About Quantum Science
authors: Ingeborg Stass; Stefan Hildebrandt
abstract: Dear Reader, Advanced Quantum Technologies was launched in late 2018, and it has already found its way into the respective scientific communities. We were pleased to receive such a warm and welcoming response by so many scientists working in the fields of quantum science, quantum optics, and quantum computing in its broadest sense. Our journal gives you a forum for fundamental and applied research in quantum computation and simulation, quantum information and control, quantum metrology, quantum optics, and related areas such as nanophotonics, quasiparticle excitations, topological materials, superconductors, micro- and nano electromechanical systems, and ultracold atoms. To see the entire keyword list, please take a look here: https://www.advancedsciencenews.com/advanced-quantum-technologies/ As a recent addition to our Editorial Advisory Board we welcome Miloš Nesládek of Hasselt University, Belgium, whose research bridges diamond technology and quantum science. The entire Advisory Board representing a wide range of research topics is listed here: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/page/journal/25119044/homepage/2820_edbd.html Quantum Machine Learning is one topic that we were exploring in a Special Issue guest-edited by Lucas Lamata, Mikel Sanz, and Enrique Solano (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/toc/25119044/2019/2/7-8). We are looking forward to a Special Issue on Photonic Quantum Technologies guest-edited by Mohamed Benyoucef, Anthony Bennett, Stephan Götzinger, and Chaoyang Lu to be published in February. This is to be followed by Rainer Blatt's Special Issue Advancing Quantum Technologies – Chances and Challenges later this year. Both Rainer Blatt and Chaoyang Lu also serve on our Advisory Board. Article types of choice range from Communications and Full Papers over comprehensive Reviews, Progress Reports, and Research News to Essays. You will find further details here: https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/pb-assets/assets/25119044/2820_Guide_for_Authors_QUTE-1561970707183.pdf Our listing of Most Accessed articles at https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/page/journal/25119044/homepage/2820_mostaccessed.html illustrates the broad range of topics that has been covered by this young journal already – from quantum photonics over topological superconductivity to 2D materials and spintronics complementing our core fields of quantum computing and information. As quantum science is clearly here to stay, this journal is for you to be explored, as readers and what's more, as our future authors. We sincerely hope that you enjoy and value our service of a timely and individual response to your inquiries, our effort of finding suitable and promptly-responding reviewers for your manuscripts, and our swift post-acceptance handling of your paper. After all, we are indebted to our authors, reviewers, Advisory Board members, and readers, for entrusting the journal with their research and expertise. We wish you all the best for a successful and pleasant year in 2020. Kind regards, Ingeborg Stass, Editor and Stefan Hildebrandt, Editor-in-Chief P.S. The editorial team is happy to receive any input and comments at advquantumtech@wiley.com

title: Quantum Interference Measurements: Quantum Interference Measurements and Their Application to Analysis of Ultrafast Photocarrier Dynamics in Semiconductor Solar Cell Materials (Adv. Quantum Technol. 1/2020)
authors: Hirokazu Tahara; Yoshihiko Kanemitsu
abstract: Quantum interference measurement allows us to analyze photocarrier physics in optoelectronic materials and devices. In article number 1900098, Hirokazu Tahara and Yoshihiko Kanemitsu review the development of quantum interference measurement and photocarrier physics in solar cell materials. The cover image describes phase-locked optical pulses and optoelectronic materials used in the quantum interference measurement. The interference signals generated by the phase-locked pulses provide beneficial information to understand multiple carrier-generation sites in solar cell materials and multiple exciton physics in semiconductor nanocrystals.

title: Inside Back Cover: Toward Arbitrary Control of Lattice Interactions in Nonequilibrium Condensates (Adv. Quantum Technol. 2/2020)
authors: Kirill P. Kalinin; Natalia G. Berloff
abstract: There is a growing interest in investigating new states of matter using out-of-equilibrium lattice spin models in two dimensions. However, a control of pairwise interactions in such systems has been elusive as due to their nonequilibrium nature they maintain nontrivial particle fluxes even at the steady state. In article number 1900065 Natalia Berloff and co-workers suggest how to overcome this problem and formulate a method for engineering reconfigurable networks of nonequilibrium condensates with control of individual pairwise interactions.

title: Inside Front Cover: Topology and Interactions in the Photonic Creutz and Creutz‐Hubbard Ladders (Adv. Quantum Technol. 2/2020)
authors: Juan Zurita; C. E. Creffield; Gloria Platero
abstract: The equations that guide the propagation of light in certain circumstances can be mapped to those of quantum mechanics. This allows the simulation of quantum systems in photonic setups such as waveguide lattices, featured in the cover image. In article number 1900105, Juan Zurita, Charles Creffield and Gloria Platero analyze the possible use of a photonic lattice to simulate a strongly-correlated topological insulator with AharonovBohm localization dynamics. The intense repulsive interaction considered can actually bind particles together, and the doublon formed in this way can feature similar dynamics to the single-particle case, but for different values of the parameters of the system.

title: Back Cover: Structural Analysis of Nuclear Spin Clusters via 2D Nanoscale Nuclear Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy (Adv. Quantum Technol. 3/2020)
authors: Zhiping Yang; Xi Kong; Zhijie Li; Kai Yang; Pei Yu; Pengfei Wang; Ya Wang; Xi Qin; Xing Rong; Chang‐Kui Duan; Fazhan Shi; Jiangfeng Du
abstract: Two-dimensional nanoscale NMR spectroscopy on a pair of coupled 13C nuclear spins with the nitrogen-vacancy sensor is demonstrated experimentally by Xi Kong, Fazhan Shi, Jiangfeng Du and co-workers, article number 1900136. The structure of the nuclear spin pair is resolved and a step-by-step route to characterize a single molecule structure is proposed for the further applications. The picture shows the coupled 13C nuclear spins (blue spots) detected by a nitrogen-vacancy sensor (the shining spot) in diamond.

title: Front Cover: Quantum Computers as Universal Quantum Simulators: State‐of‐the‐Art and Perspectives (Adv. Quantum Technol. 3/2020)
authors: Francesco Tacchino; Alessandro Chiesa; Stefano Carretta; Dario Gerace
abstract: Qubit-based quantum processors can be programmed to compute the dynamics of a large class of complex many-body models. The cover gives a pictorial view of the key ingredients allowing to perform quantum computer simulations: a mathematical description of the dynamics of a physical system and its mapping on a spin lattice representation, which can ultimately be encoded onto a given quantum hardware backend. In article number 1900052, Dario Gerace and co-workers review the relevant theoretical background and the main technological platforms currently realizing this paradigm.

title: Front Cover: A 3D Polymeric Platform for Photonic Quantum Technologies (Adv. Quantum Technol. 7/2020)
authors: Maja Colautti; Pietro Lombardi; Marco Trapuzzano; Francesco S. Piccioli; Sofia Pazzagli; Bruno Tiribilli; Sara Nocentini; F. S. Cataliotti; Diederik S. Wiersma; Costanza Toninelli
abstract: A major challenge in quantum technologies is the on-chip integration of quantum emitters in a way that can be scaled up and preserves the emitter coherence properties. In the unconventional platform presented by Costanza Toninelli and co-workers in article number 2000004, molecular single-photon sources are embedded in three-dimensional polymeric structures, obtained by direct laser writing. Anthracene nanocrystals doped with dibenzoterrylene chromophores (chemical structure in the zoom) are previously selected and integrated in a scalable way, without perturbing the emitter optical features. In particular, suspended waveguides are designed to route the emitted fluorescence towards convenient output modes while micro-dome solid immersion lenses efficiently redirect the emission enabling unprecedented collected single-photon rates from a cold molecule.

title: Front Cover: Isotropic Scalar Quantum Sensing of Magnetic Fields for Industrial Application (Adv. Quantum Technol. 8/2020)
authors: Robert Staacke; Roger John; Ralf Wunderlich; Ludwig Horsthemke; Wolfgang Knolle; Christian Laube; Peter Glösekötter; B. Burchard; Bernd Abel; Jan Meijer
abstract: The cover shows a variety of diamond nanoparticles with a high concentration of nitrogen-vacancy centers. The bright red fluorescence of these particles depends on the strength of the magnetic field represented by field lines. With a stronger magnetic field the fluorescence is quenched due to spin mixing. Additionally, the field direction dependency is averaged out through the number of nanoparticles. This enables the creation of a robust isotropic quantum sensor for magnetic fields, as demonstrated by Robert Staacke and co-workers in article number 2000037.

title: Front Cover: Topological Sound Pumping of Zero‐Dimensional Bound States (Adv. Quantum Technol. 9/2020)
authors: Penglin Gao; Johan Christensen
abstract: A Majorana-like bound state can be engineered in artificial acoustic lattices thanks to a Jackiw–Rossi vortex, which is the analog of a topological superconductor vortex. Such vortex is created by introducing a Kekulé texture to the man-made lattice of rigid cylinders. In article number 2000065, Penglin Gao and Johan Christensen show how this binding mechanism can be well explained by a topological pumping process comprising adiabatic variations of the cylinder radii, which concentrates strong acoustic energy to the lattice center as shown in the cover image.

title: Advancing Quantum Technologies – Chances and Challenges
authors: R. Blatt
abstract: The development of quantum mechanics and quantum physics in general is one of the greatest intellectual achievements of the 20th century. Initially, quantum physicists focused on mathematically describing and understanding the laws of a micro-world, comprised of atoms, molecules and photons. Nuclei and sub-atomic particles were discovered, particle physics evolved, and complex quantum systems in chemistry and solid-state physics are now described in terms of quantum physics. Within a century, quantum physics became the framework, which allows us to describe and predict, albeit with probabilities, the behavior of the microscopic world as we know it. The powerful quantum framework led to revolutionary technical advances for a century, such as semiconductor technology and the entire electronics industry based on it, enabling computers and the information age. The development of lasers found applications in many areas of our current technologies; we use them for printers, storing and retrieving information using CDs, industrial welding, medical surgery, and for range finding and communication purposes. Medical imaging using MRI is now a routine instrument, as are precision measurements using tunneling and atomic force microscopes. Superconducting technologies are used for high magnetic fields and many more current technologies are based on and enabled by the laws of quantum physics. While the framework of quantum physics has thus proven to be extremely successful and powerful, throughout the last century there were many conceptual, and to some extent philosophical, discussions on our understanding of quantum physics. As early as the 1930s, Einstein and Schrödinger realized that quantum physics allows for some peculiar states, which Schrödinger called “entangled”, which have a non-local character and thus do find an easy interpretation in our classical world. It took a few more decades until John Bell conceived a way to quantify such states, which thus became amenable to measurements. Only in the eighties and nineties of the last century did the generation of entangled states, their characterization and their subsequent application become feasible and accessible in laboratories. Early on, Bell states were proposed for applications in quantum communication, employing protocols based on teleportation. Soon, entanglement was recognized to be useful also for sensing, for precision measurements and eventually for quantum information processing. Starting with the early concept of a trapped-ion quantum computer introduced by Ignacio Cirac and Peter Zoller in 1995, many other platforms were proposed for quantum information processing, based on superconducting quantum bits, photonic processes, engineered quantum dots and many more. The first decade of the 21st century saw an explosive development of quantum information physics, which is by now a mature field and increasingly focuses on applications. Worldwide efforts are ongoing to realize quantum networks for secure communication and to implement quantum computers. Enhanced sensing has been demonstrated using advanced quantum states, and quantum simulators have been developed, already tackling problems that are hard to compute with classical computers. While architectures for full-fledged quantum computers are already available, the realization of such computers still requires the routine implementation of error correction, which is not yet available, for full scalability. Currently, noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) processors are already used for computations and are even accessible via cloud services. Since about 2000, quantum technologies have been developed for many platforms with the aim to surpass the capablities of their classical counterparts. Many such devices now make use of entangled states, which are seen as the new resource for advanced quantum technologies. For this, describing, understanding and generally mastering the generation and manipulation of entanglement is a key element. Moreover, both hardware and software technologies have to be improved in order to better control quantum devices. Mastering quantum phenomena for communication, metrology, simulation and computation purposes is currently one of the hottest topics in science since the wide applicability of quantum technologies will revolutionize these fields. The development of advanced quantum technologies is thus seen worldwide as a strategic area for generating technical knowledge and industrial evolution. This special issue intends to showcase the breadth and impact of the ongoing research in advancing quantum technologies. We have invited a selection of renowned scientists to present their work, and we are confident that this issue will find a broad readership and attract much interest within the scientific community.

title: Back Cover: Probing Proximity‐Tailored High Spin–Orbit Coupling in 2D Materials (Adv. Quantum Technol. 9/2020)
authors: Krishna Rani Sahoo; T. Pradeep Chakravarthy; Rahul Sharma; Sumit Bawari; Suman Mundlia; Satyaki Sasmal; Karthik V. Raman; Tharangattu N. Narayanan; Nirmal K. Viswanathan
abstract: Simultaneous extraction of the magnetic and spin-orbit coupling (SOC) information of an interface using the weak measurement assisted spin-Hall effect of light (SHEL) is demonstrated as a novel probe to characterize materials' magnetic properties, see article number 2000042 by Karthik V. Raman, Tharangattu N. Narayanan, Nirmal K. Viswanathan, and co-workers. A heterostructure of Fe and MoS2 monolayers is shown for enhanced SOC due to the proximity effect, which is proven via SHEL method and then confirmed using magneto-optic Kerr effect (MOKE) studies.

title: Front Cover: Single‐Particle Entanglement (Adv. Quantum Technol. 10/2020)
authors: Stefano Azzini; Sonia Mazzucchi; Valter Moretti; Davide Pastorello; Lorenzo Pavesi
abstract: The cover shows the input stage of a setup to produce single-particle entangled states of photons where the momentum and polarization degrees of freedom are entangled (see the formula). A classical light source formed by a green light-emitting diode is used. The data in the plot show the violation of the Bell inequality by the single-particle entangled states. Pictorially a Schrödinger cat is testing the photon beam (image author Bianca Moretti). For further details on single-particle entanglement see the Review by Lorenzo Pavesi and co-workers, article number 2000014.

title: Back Cover: Parallel Ghost Imaging (Adv. Quantum Technol. 10/2020)
authors: Xiaodong Qiu; Dongkai Zhang; Tianlong Ma; Fei Lin; Haoxu Guo; Wuhong Zhang; Lixiang Chen
abstract: Based on two-photon hyperentanglement – that is, two photons simultaneously entangled in polarization, color (wavelength), and spatial modes – Lixiang Chen and co-workers develop a new parallel ghost imaging system of different independent imaging channels (see article number 2000073). These channels are encoded and sustained by polarization and wavelength multiplexing while in each channel spatial entanglement is always maintained to convey the ghost images in parallel.

title: Back Cover: Hydrogen‐Intercalated Graphene on SiC as Platform for Hybrid Superconductor Devices (Adv. Quantum Technol. 12/2020)
authors: Fabian Paschke; Tobias Birk; Stiven Forti; Ulrich Starke; Mikhail Fonin
abstract: In article number 2000082, Fabian Paschke, Mikhail Fonin and co-workers report on the atomic-scale study of electronic properties and the superconducting proximity effect in hydrogen-intercalated graphene on SiC decorated with epitaxial lead (Pb) islands. Scanning tunneling spectroscopy confirms a quasi-free-standing nature of the graphene layer. The variations of the proximity-induced superconducting gap on graphene are measured as function of spatial position as well as of magnetic field strength. The findings of this study pave the way for the large-scale fabrication of graphene–superconductor heterostructures, which can be implemented for quantum information processing.

title: Front Cover: Interference in Atomic Magnetometry (Adv. Quantum Technol. 12/2020)
authors: Min Jiang; Wenjie Xu; Qing Li; Ze Wu; Dieter Suter; Xinhua Peng
abstract: A novel interference effect in atomic magnetometers is uncovered and characterized, which introduces an important systematic error to greatly deteriorate the accuracy of magnetic-field measurements (see article number 2000078 by Xinhua Peng and co-workers). Such an effect provides a first explanation for the phenomenon of asymmetric spectra observed in ultra-low-field nuclear magnetic resonance. It is anticipated that the magnetic interference phenomena uncovered here will stimulate interesting new researches in a wide range of magnetometers and their applications in biological, physical, and chemical science.

title: Exciting News from QUTE
authors: Ingeborg Stass; Huan Wang; Matteo Cavalleri; Stefan Hildebrandt
abstract: Dear Reader, We are pleased to share the news that Advanced Quantum Technologies (QUTE) has been promoted to the Science Citation Index Expanded (SCIE) by Web of Science. Consequently, it will receive a Journal Impact Factor in its upcoming 2022 Journal Citation Report release. As of now, QUTE ranks 21/113 in the Optics category of Web of Science, and 6/21 in its Quantum Science & Technology category. This corresponds to the quartiles Q1 and Q2, respectively. Being in its fifth year QUTE had already been included in the Emerging Sources Citation Index (ESCI) of Web of Science. It acknowledges the journal as an established international and peer-reviewed publication in the emerging field of quantum science and technology. As such, QUTE articles have already been indexed in Web of Science. You may be aware that our journal focuses on Quantum Science in general, and on Quantum Computing, Quantum Optics, Quantum Communication, Quantum Sensing, Quantum Metrology, and Quantum Materials in particular. Submitted articles may range from fundamentals to technologies. To illustrate our journal's scope we would like to point you to a selection of articles that were particularly well received, see Table 1. Now look at how versatile QUTE is! title: Front Cover: Magneto‐Optical Sensing Beyond the Shot Noise Limit (Adv. Quantum Technol. 1/2022)
authors: Yun‐Yi Pai; Claire E. Marvinney; Chengyun Hua; Raphael C. Pooser; Benjamin J. Lawrie
abstract: Classical magneto-optical microscopies are workhorse tools for materials characterization, but they are fundamentally limited in sensitivity by the photon shot noise limit. Quantum mechanical light sources guarantee that the aforementioned “standard quantum limit” is beaten. In article number 2100107, Yun-Yi Pai, Raphael C. Pooser, Benjamin J. Lawrie, and co-workers describe quantum enhanced magneto-optical Kerr effect measurements that are accessible with today's quantum optical resources – an optical parametric amplifier. This approach to quantum sensing of quantum materials enables 10 nrad/√Hz sensitivity at temperatures well below 100 mK. [Cover design by Yun-Yi Pai]

authors: Si‐Si Gu; Bao‐Chuan Wang; Mingbo Chen; Ting Lin; Yuan Kang; Hai‐Ou Li; Gang Cao; Guo‐Ping Guo
abstract: Circuit quantum electrodynamics architecture provides a controllable artificial system and enriches the physics with the participation of electron-photon interaction. The cover shows this hybrid architecture comprised of a superconducting microwave resonator and a triple quantum dot. In article number 2100104, Si-Si Gu and colleagues investigate quantum cellular automata and “photon-assisted” quadruple point phenomena in this system, which involve the Coulomb interaction among multiple dots and the simultaneously-tunneling processes assisted with cavity photons. authors: V. S. Stolyarov; Dimitri Roditchev; В. Л. Гуртовой; Sergey N. Kozlov; Dmitry S. Yakovlev; Olga V. Skryabina; V. M. Vinokur; A. A. Golubov
abstract: In article number 2100124, Vasily S. Stolyarov and colleagues have observed unexpectedly fine (≈1 Oe) resonant oscillations of the critical Josephson current in the magnetic field in ballistic Nb-Bi2Te2.3Se0.7-Nb proximity junctions at temperatures below 500 mK. The peaked maxima of oscillations are attributed to the resonant transmission of quasiparticles through low-lying Andreev bound states forming at the superconductor-topological insulator interfaces owing to the p-wave component of the induced superconducting order.

title: Negative Shannon Information Hides Networks
authors: M. X. Luo
abstract: Abstract Shannon information is defined for characterizing the uncertainty information of classical probabilistic distributions. As an uncertainty measure it is generally believed to be positive. This holds for any information quantity from two random variables because of the polymatroidal axioms. However, it is unknown why there is negative information for more than two random variables on finite dimensional spaces. It is first shown that the negative tripartite Shannon mutual information implies specific Bayesian network representations of its joint distribution. Then it is shown that the negative Shannon information is obtained from general tripartite Bayesian networks with quantum realizations. This provides a device‐independent witness of negative Shannon information. Finally the result is extended for general networks. The present result shows new insights in the network compatibility from non‐Shannon information inequalities.

abstract: In article number 2200028, Wu-Hao Cai, Ying Tian, Rui-Bo Jin, and colleagues exploit the particle swarm optimization algorithm to design lithium niobate for generating spectrally-pure single photons at mid-infrared wavelengths. abstract: Quantum key distribution (QKD) is one of the most mature applications of single photon sources. The cover image shows on demand generation of single photons and their subsequent polarization encoding to prepare flying qubits in QKD. In article number 2200059, Çağlar Samaner and colleagues implement an isolated defect in hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) as the efficient single photon source and control their polarization by an electro-optic modulator to demonstrate free-space B92 based QKD. abstract: Investigation of promising spin-qubit candidates in solid materials is vital for scalable noisy intermediate scale quantum (NISQ) technologies. As demonstrated by Hailong Wang, Heng Yuan, and colleagues in article number 2200044, a symmetry-protected two-level system (qubit) based on the H3 center in diamond with C2v symmetry is characterized, which is capable of applications in quantum information processing. title: Predestined Steady‐State Entanglement under Pure Vacuum Noise
authors: Yuebing Zhou; Jiawei Hu; Hongwei Yu
abstract: Abstract Ever since the seminal work by Yu and Eberly [Phys. Rev. Lett. 93 , 140404 (2004)], it has become widely accepted that nonlocal entanglement is more fragile than local coherence, in the sense that even under the influence of pure vacuum noise, the two‐qubit entanglement may end within a finite time, while the single‐qubit coherence always decays exponentially. By contrast, in this paper, it is shown that, for a pair of rotating qubits under pure vacuum noise with appropriate orbital radius and angular velocity, nonlocal entanglement as compared to local coherence is not only more resilient against vacuum noise to be preserved in the steady‐state for initially entangled states, but more importantly is also predestined to be created and be preserved for initially separable states. The generation of predestined entanglement here is essentially different from the dissipative steady‐state entanglement generation in existing schemes insofar as it is inevitably generated in pure vacuum instead of an elaborately designed environment.

title: Back Cover: The Origin of Quantum Effects in Low‐Dimensional Thermoelectric Materials (Adv. Quantum Technol. 1/2021)
authors: Nguyen Tuan Hung; Riichiro Saito
abstract: In article number 2000115, Nguyen Tuan Hung and Riichiro Saito report on the origin of the quantum effects to improve the thermoelectricity of low-dimensional materials. The power factor enhances when the confinement length (diameter of 1D materials or the thickness of 2D materials) is smaller than the thermal de Broglie wavelength, which is established as a crucial parameter to enhance the thermoelectricity. The cover image depicts electrons moving from hot to cold temperature, which can generate electrical energy. The quantum effect occurs when the width of the system is smaller than the thermal de Broglie wavelength.

title: Quantum Chaos and the Spectrum of Factoring
authors: José Luis Rosales; Samira Briongos; Vicente Martín
abstract: Abstract The factorization ensemble is a set to which integer factorable numbers , having the same trivial factorization complexity, belong. Hence, the Rivest‐Shamir‐Adleman (RSA) cryptographic moduli pertain to this set. A function can be defined therein which will be associated to the energy of a system of ions in a Penning trap. This is the quantum factoring simulator hypothesis connecting quantum mechanics with number theory. Here, a possible setup of the simulator from the magnetron energies of a Coulomb crystal in a cylindrical trap is described. Then, quantum mechanically, these energies may have only discrete values. To test the validity of the simulator hypothesis, evidence of this kind of discreteness from the statistics of the of a large random sample of RSA moduli is reported; indeed, their unfolded distance probability distribution fits to a Gaussian Unitary Ensemble, exactly as required if they actually correspond to the quantum energy levels spacing of a magnetically confined system that exhibits chaos. The confirmation of these predictions is consistent with the quantum simulator hypothesis and, thereby, it points to the existence of a liaison between quantum mechanics and number theory.

title: Front Cover: Enhanced Spin Hall Effect in S‐Implanted Pt (Adv. Quantum Technol. 1/2021)
authors: Utkarsh Shashank; Rohit Medwal; Taiga Shibata; Razia Nongjai; Joseph Vimal Vas; Martial Duchamp; K. Asokan; Rajdeep Singh Rawat; Hironori Asada; Surbhi Gupta; Yasuhiro Fukuma
abstract: The spin Hall effect is a spin–orbit-coupling-related phenomenon, in which the charge current generates a transverse spin current and vice versa. Platinum is a well explored spin Hall material due to large spin–orbit coupling and high conductivity, but its interconversion efficiency is of around 10% only. In article number 2000112, Surbhi Gupta, Yasuhiro Fukuma, and co-workers employ the pioneering technology of ion implantation to develop a new spin Hall material, sulfur-implanted platinum Pt(S), demonstrating an interconversion efficiency of 50%. The designed Pt(S) achieves high spin Hall conductivity, which determines its suitability for next-generation spin–orbit-torque-driven logic and memory device applications.

title: Towards a Quantum Future
authors: Ingeborg Stass; Matteo Cavalleri; James Daniel Cook; Daisy Diao; Heike Höpcke; Melanie Rettenmaier; Huan Wang; Stefan Hildebrandt
abstract: Dear Reader, Since the launch of our journal Advanced Quantum Technologies (QUTE for short) in 2018, we have been witnessing plenty of very promising research initiatives and activities in the diverse fields of quantum science, quantum materials, and quantum technologies. Key questions like “Where is quantum technology taking us? What are challenges and perspectives?” led our Editorial Advisor Rainer Blatt to edit a special issue Advancing Quantum Technologies – Chances and Challenges that we published in November 2020 (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/toc/25119044/2020/3/11). It broadly showcases how to master quantum phenomena for communication, metrology, sensing, simulation, and computation purposes. In a related virtual mini-symposium Rainer Blatt invited the authors Christoph Becher, Dagmar Bruss, Klemens Hammerer, Dieter Meschede, Christian Ospelkaus, and Robert Raussendorf to share their visions of the quantum future, which culminated in a vivid discussion (https://www.workcast.com/register?cpak=6284277449925096). Yet another recent quantum science webinar targeting a large Chinese audience featured our authors Tongcang Li and Yongjian Han who gave talks on quantum simulation in optical systems and quantum spin optomechanics, respectively. Further activities are being planned for 2021 in order to stay in close contact with the quantum community even during the pandemic. Earlier in 2020 Mohamed Benyoucef, Anthony Bennett, Stephan Götzinger, and Chaoyang Lu threw the spotlight on Photonic Quantum Technologies by editing a special issue (https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/toc/25119044/2020/3/2). The topics addressed include hybrid integration of single-photon emitters, cavity QED and light–matter interactions at the nanoscale, on-chip integration of entangled photon sources, and incorporating color centers into nanophotonic structures. Fabrication of suspended converters, single-photon emission at the telecom wavelength, molecule-based single-photon sources, quantum emitter–plasmonic cavity coupling, vertically coupled quantum dot systems, and optomechanical coupling are also discussed. authors: Lorenzo Rocutto; C. Destri; Enrico Prati
abstract: The cover image shows an artistic impression of the graph of connections between the qubits of an adiabatic quantum computer, merged with a brain-shaped network. The latter reminds the semantic learning implemented by the quantum artificial intelligence agent operating as the quantum version of a restricted Boltzmann machine on a D-Wave quantum computer. For further information see the invited research article by Lorenzo Rocutto, Claudio Destri and Enrico Prati, article number 2000133. (Image design by E. Prati.)

title: Front Cover: Label‐Free Phase Change Detection of Lipid Bilayers Using Nanoscale Diamond Magnetometry (Adv. Quantum Technol. 4/2021)
authors: Hitoshi Ishiwata; Hiroshi Watanabe; Shinya Hanashima; Takayuki Iwasaki; Mutsuko Hatano
abstract: The diffusion constant of a lipid bilayer, a biological parameter that determines the dynamics of the lipid bilayer, was determined by making use of the extremely small detection volume offered by nanoscale nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) using nitrogen vacancy (NV) center in diamond. Observation of the diffusion constant at different temperature reveals different phases of the lipid bilayer. The result builds a foundation for label-free imaging of cell membranes for the observation of phase composition and pristine dynamics that determine cellular functions. For further details see article number 2000106 by Hitoshi Ishiwata and co-workers.

title: Back Cover: Quantum Sensing of Insulator‐to‐Metal Transitions in a Mott Insulator (Adv. Quantum Technol. 5/2021)
authors: Nathan J. McLaughlin; Yoav Kalcheim; Albert Suceava; Hailong L. Wang; Iván K. Schuller; Chunhui Du
abstract: The back cover of this issue, referring to article number 2000142 by Chunhui Rita Du and co-workers, represents the authors' work on measuring insulator-to-metal transition in a Mott insulator using nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers in diamond. An optically active NV center works as a nanoscale quantum sensor to locally probe the temperature and magnetic field environment of the current filaments between gold contacts on a film of vanadium dioxide, revealing the fundamental mechanism of insulator-to-metal transition. This research highlights the opportunities offered by NV centers in exploring nanoscale thermal and electrical behaviors in Mott materials which might have applications in developing cutting-edge neuromorphic computing platforms. [Cover design: Gerald Yan]

title: Front Cover: Generating Discorrelated States for Quantum Information Protocols by Coherent Multimode Photon Addition (Adv. Quantum Technol. 5/2021)
authors: Nicola Biagi; Luca Costanzo; Marco Bellini; Alessandro Zavatta
abstract: Discorrelation is a new form of exclusive photon-number anti-correlation of multimode quantum light states, whereby measurements of the number of photons in different modes never return the same results. Discorrelated states can be used in quantum information protocols to distribute unique randomness between parties, such as implementing mental-poker schemes between distant players, without the need for a trusted card dealer. In article number 2000141, Nicola Biagi, Alessandro Zavatta and co-workers present the first experimental generation of discorrelated light states, obtained by coherently sharing a single photon (pictorially represented by the red sphere in the foreground) between two weak laser pulses (the two bell-like red shapes).

title: Back Cover: Deterministic Integration of hBN Emitter in Silicon Nitride Photonic Waveguide (Adv. Quantum Technol. 6/2021)
authors: Ali W. Elshaari; Anas Skalli; Samuel Gyger; Martin Nurizzo; Lucas Schweickert; Iman Esmaeil Zadeh; Mikael Svedendahl; Stephan Steinhauer; Val Zwiller
abstract: This cover image (referring to article number 2100032 by Ali W. Elshaari and co-workers) is an artistic representation of hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) single-photon sources, shown as dipole emitters, deterministically integrated in photonic waveguides. The emitters are encapsulated in the waveguide-material using plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition, this is highlighted by peeling the waveguiding layer revealing activated hBN emitters on the substrate. The process is fully deterministic in selecting the quantum sources and their precise placement in any photonic structure, at the same time maintaining the high quality of the emission.

title: Back Cover: Erasable Superconductivity in Topological Insulator Bi<sub>2</sub>Se<sub>3</sub> Induced by Voltage Pulse (Adv. Quantum Technol. 9/2021)
authors: Tian Le; Qikai Ye; Chufan Chen; Lichang Yin; Dongting Zhang; Xiaozhi Wang; Xin Lü
abstract: Emergent superconductivity is observed in the local mesoscopic point-contacts on the topological insulator Bi2Se3 by applying a voltage pulse through the Ag contacts. The superconductivity can be erased with thermal cycles by warming up to high temperatures (300 K) and repeatedly induced by the voltage pulse at base temperature (1.9 K), suggesting a significance for designing new types of quantum devices. For further details, see article number 2100067 by Tian Le, Xiaozhi Wang, Xin Lu and co-workers.

title: Front Cover: Photonic Jet Writing of Quantum Dots Self‐Aligned to Dielectric Microspheres (Adv. Quantum Technol. 9/2021)
authors: Andrea Ristori; Travis Hamilton; Dimosthenis Toliopoulos; Marco Felici; Giorgio Pettinari; S. Sanguinetti; Massimo Gurioli; Hooman Mohseni; Francesco Biccari
abstract: Quantum dots (QDs) are promising candidates for the large-scale implementation of quantum information technologies. In article number 2100045, Andrea Ristori, Francesco Biccari and co-workers present a novel laser writing technique based on the properties of dielectric microspheres and on the effects of hydrogen in dilute nitrides. This technique enables the fabrication of GaAs1−xNx QDs self-aligned to the microspheres, leading to a 7-fold enhancement of their luminescence collection with a NA = 0.7 objective. This simple approach can lead to new QD-based devices.

title: Front Cover: Optimal Pump Shaping for Entanglement Control in Any Countable Basis (Adv. Quantum Technol. 10/2021)
authors: Nicholas Bornman; Wagner Tavares Buono; Michael Lovemore; Andrew Forbes
abstract: Quantum entangled states are often produced by pumping a non-linear crystal with a Gaussian beam and then measuring the entangled photons in some basis. In article number 2100066, Nicholas Bornman, Andrew Forbes and co-workers show how to deterministically alter the pump light's shape for a desired output quantum state, expressed in any spatial mode basis (pattern of light). Because there are an infinite number of possible structured light patterns, their use for creation and detection of quantum states opens exciting prospects for high-dimensional entanglement control.

title: Back Cover: Magnetic Topological Semimetal Phase with Electronic Correlation Enhancement in SmSbTe (Adv. Quantum Technol. 10/2021)
authors: K. C. Pandey; Debashis Mondal; John W. Villanova; Joseph E. Roll; Rabindra Basnet; Aaron Wegner; Gokul Acharya; Md Rafique Un Nabi; Barun Ghosh; Jun Fujii; Jian Wang; Bo Da; Amit Agarwal; I. Vobornik; Antonio Politano; Salvador Barraza‐Lopez; Jin Hu
abstract: Topological materials are a promising platform for a wide range of next-generation technologies. In article number 2100063, Antonio Politano, Salvador Barraza-Lopez, Jin Hu and co-workers report a new topological material, SmSbTe, displaying a coexistence of magnetism, enhanced electronic correlations, and Dirac fermions, as illustrated in the cover image. This discovery suggests that SmSbTe represents an ideal platform for exotic quantum phenomena arising from the interplay between degrees of freedom. The manipulation of these phenomena would further pave a path for quantum material-based functional devices.

title: Front Cover: Lifting the Spin‐Momentum Locking in Ultra‐Thin Topological Insulator Films (Adv. Quantum Technol. 11/2021)
authors: Arthur Leis; Michael Schleenvoigt; Vasily Cherepanov; Felix Lüpke; Peter Schüffelgen; Gregor Mußler; Detlev Grützmacher; Bert Voigtländer; F. Stefan Tautz
abstract: In article number 2100083, Arthur Leis, Bert Voigtländer and co-workers demonstrate nanoscale four-probe measurements on atomically thin topological insulator films. For this purpose, four individual scanning tunneling microscope tips are directly contacting individual terraces on the sample surface to quantify the thickness-dependent film conductivity. This enables the authors to detect a breakdown of spin-momentum locking in the topological surface state as a function of the film thickness. In the few-layer limit, this effect can realize helical edge modes along step edges with potential applications in spintronics and quantum computing.

title: Back Cover: Coherent Ising Machines with Optical Error Correction Circuits (Adv. Quantum Technol. 11/2021)
authors: Sam Reifenstein; Satoshi Kako; Farad Khoyratee; Timothée Leleu; Y. Yamamoto
abstract: The graph on the cover shows the evolution of average energies of many trajectories in a coherent Ising machine (CIM). In some cases, the final state of CIM reaches a ground state (solution), while in some other cases the CIM states are trapped in the first, second and third excited states (non-solution). The CIM is a noise-driven stochastic computing machine and this image shows such a random character. For further information see article number 2100077 by Yoshihisa Yamamoto and co-workers.

title: Front Cover: Scalable Creation of Deep Silicon‐Vacancy Color Centers in Diamond by Ion Implantation through a 1‐µm Pinhole (Adv. Quantum Technol. 12/2021)
authors: L. Hunold; S. Lagomarsino; Assegid M. Flatae; Haritha Kambalathmana; Florian Sledz; S. Sciortino; N. Gelli; L. Giuntini; Mario Agio
abstract: Diamond color centers represent a promising resource for quantum photonics applications. Various approaches based on ion implantation have been developed for their controlled creation, but only at shallow depths. In article number 2100079, Lukas Hunold, Mario Agio, and co-workers show the ability to produce diamond color centers with a lateral precision of 1 µm at depths down to 1 µm and they discuss methods to improve the resolution further. These findings facilitate the post-fabrication of photonic structures and post-processing of diamond-based devices.

title: Back Cover: An STM Perspective on Hexaborides: Surface States of the Kondo Insulator SmB<sub>6</sub> (Adv. Quantum Technol. 12/2021)
authors: S. Wirth; P. Schlottmann
abstract: Experimental efforts are required to confirm the recently proposed topologically non-trivial nature of the surface states in SmB6. The cover shows the scanning tunneling microscopy set-up for the topography and spectroscopy measurements on hexaborides used by Steffen Wirth and Pedro Schlottmann (see article number 2100102). Shown is the topography of a SmB6 surface (5.1 nm Ã— 5.5 nm) and a scanning electron microscopy image of a tungsten tip (shaft diameter about 0.3 mm). Tunneling spectroscopy provides local information on the electronic sample properties, in particular the density of states near the sample surface.

title: Dissipative Generation of Two‐Mode Mechanical Squeezing via Frequency Modulation
authors: Tian‐Qi Zhang; Dongyang Wang; Cheng‐Hua Bai; Shou Zhang; Hong‐Fu Wang
abstract: Abstract Different from the general schemes of two‐mode mechanical squeezing, a dissipative scheme to generate strong and robust two‐mode mechanical squeezing via frequency modulation of cavity modes in a cavity optomechanical system consisting of a modulated two‐mode optical cavity and two mechanical oscillators is proposed. It is shown that the strong mechanical squeezing, which is highly robust against the thermal noise, can be engineered by means of cavity dissipation. Moreover, the squeezing mechanism is explored via analytical approach and it is found that the squeezing direction is controlled by modulation amplitude. The scheme provides an alternative pathway to generate strong mechanical–mechanical entanglement.

abstract: Researchers from Louisiana introduce a smart quantum technology for the spatial mode correction of single photons. In article number 2000103, Narayan Bhusal, Chenglong You, and co-workers exploit the self-learning and self-evolving features of artificial neural networks to correct the distorted spatial profile of single photons. The authors report a near-unity fidelity in the correction of spatial modes of light. This technique boosts the channel capacity of optical communication protocols that rely on structured photons. This work has important implications for quantum technologies operating at the single-photon level.
